comment.author: 39839593@N00
comment._content:
Is the road unpaved or just dirty?

And a lot more ghosts in the late 19th century.

comment.author: 52585175@N07
comment._content:
Must be an unpaved road! So many ghosts!!  ;) 
It could almost be in France?

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/govert1970] I'm voting for unpaved. Lots of ghosts, even a ghostly horse and cart...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Bing do a nice Bird's Eye View of Lurgan.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: This appears to be from before the Market House and other buildings from the middle of the street were cleared. The OS 6" map from the mid-19th century shows them still, and this Lurgan Ancestry page says they were gone by 1896.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] So 1885 mightn't be too wildly astray?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Slaters National Commercial Directory is excerpted at that Ancestry page, and says Cullenan's was there in 1880, but not in 1865. Cullenan's was there in 1877, too. So, date is after 1865, before 1896.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] Fantastic, Niall. So hopefully with other evidence we can chip away at the outer edges of 1865 and 1896 too...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content:
Not conclusive, but the 1865 directory lists 4 businesses on Middle Row, the 1877 Lennon Wylie link above lists two, and the 1880 lists none. I think most of Middle Row was vacant/demolished in 1880.

The buildings to the left look in poor shape here, you can see the outline of a demolished house on the gable of the farthest house. I think this photo is in the middle of the Town Commisioners efforts to get rid of Middle Row, maybe1879?

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/govert1970] Roads were not paved with Tarmac until the early 20th century. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tarmac Before that was the dusty Macadam rolled stone paving. In dry weather the dust was laid using a water cart. The surface would then turn to mud. www.flickr.com/photos/lselibrary/6897213773/

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland]  The 3 "ghosts" on the pavement are the same bloke, probably Charlie Chaplin moonlighting.
It shows the photographer was using a long exposure in the early years of photography.

comment.author: 64555638@N00
comment._content:
The photograph has been taken from quite a high angle.
I mean the camera is not at street level.
Not quite as high as the first floor windows. Maybe on top of some sort of wagon.
Also, the white sky <u>might</u> point to it being a wet plate collodion photo.

comment.author: 54708393@N08
comment._content: Perhaps a mobile darkroom wagon setup like this.You have to admire the effort required to take single photo back then.The photographic plates had to be prepared.exposed and processed on location within a matter of minutes.

comment.author: 7945368@N05
comment._content: The horse and cart isn't a ghost.  it's just really fast, and left behind a Road Runner style dusty outline of itself when they tore off.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: An interesting point of comparison between this shot and the Shop St. Galway one is the quantity of boxes/trunks/materials left out on the side of the street.  As though left their for collection or for delivery?  Great contrast but it is a pity that the 1990's snapper did not try harder to recreate the original angle - or am I being too picky??

comment.author: 64555638@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] Not being picky at all. The 1990's photographer wasn't even trying. A drive by.

comment.author: 7945368@N05
comment._content: In fairness, looking at the amount of traffic in the 1990 photo, it would have been fairly dangerous to stop in the middle of the road to take the same angle.

comment.author: 54708393@N08
comment._content: Generally speaking the quality of many of the 1990 shots leave a lot to be desired compared to the earlier images.

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: The old OSNI map shows the building line projecting into Market Street. The photographer could have been at a first-floor window. Pity there is no way to link directly to OSNI coordinates. maps.osni.gov.uk/MapConsoleHistoricalMaps.aspx Here it is on Google Street View

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] Really happy to put 1879 as date, unless anyone else objects. Thanks Niall.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/blackpoolbeach] I know, but still like to think they're ghosts. Soppy, but there you are.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/54708393@N08] That Library of Congress photo is absolutely gorgeous, thanks.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/eyelightfilms] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/54708393@N08] As [http://www.flickr.com/photos/joefuz] says, modern traffic, and the lack of a building in Middle Row in 1990 (as [http://www.flickr.com/photos/blackpoolbeach] points out) would make it pretty difficult to replicate the exact angle. With my clock obsession, I was pleased about the 10.15/10.30 synchronicity(?) between the two photos.

I think we've all become accustomed on here to the pin sharpness of the old glass plates produced by professional photographers like Robert French (Lawrence Collection) and Arthur Henri Poole (Poole Collection)...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Another advantage we have today over 1990 is that when trying to match a shot with a digital camera, we can take 20 snaps and pick the closest. Not so easy/cheap with film in 1990.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Am I right in thinking that the 1990 photo is from the wrong location / block, apart from the wrong angle?  From the excellent comments and map links above, it seems that Robert French was at the Castle Lane junction (upstairs in the sticky-out terrace),  and  G.W.V. Whitcroft was at the corner of Windsor Avenue.  (Apologies to anyone who might have mentioned this previously)

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia]  I agree with you about the corner of Windsor Avenue being wrong.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/joefuz] Sorry I missed your explanation on the horse and cart and I guess you could be right.  Possibly an early form of turbo charging?

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] I was conscious when commenting that we are not comparing like with like when we can flick(r) through two images side by side on a computer screen while the good Mr. Whitcroft may have been working from memory of an image he had seen previously.  As Niall rightly points out we could take 20 to 200 shots of the same scene and discard those that did not measure up, not so in 1990.  Thats why this site is so addictive and enjoyable.  By the way Carol what do you mean by highlighting the word "Professional" above?  Are you casting aspersions;-}

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] No asparagus being cast here, I assure you! Will unhighlight immediately...  :)
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] Oh Carol, you've just spoiled my day, I was looking forward to one of Brendan Behans famous splits!  We could set up the Provisional NLI or whatever.

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] We don't know how many glass plates the professional photographer exposed to be sure of getting one good photo. In the 1990s some mad keen amateurs used to shoot a whole roll of 35mm 36 exposure on one scene, pretending to be David Bailey. Not me, though.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/blackpoolbeach] He was married to Catherine Deneuve??? I always fancied her, she was gorgeous, janey mack, married to Catherine Deneuve, I''ll be dreaming her tonight and probably throw her indoors out the window.  On second thoughts she can read my mind on everything else I had better not.  I have to admit that like you I did not shoot a whole roll of film on the one scene, unless it was family and then I got into trouble.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/blackpoolbeach] Catherine Deneuve? Steady now, boys, think of your collective blood pressures...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 7945368@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] Fuelled on high octane carrots?

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] Didn't someone here say recently they'd set up the Continuity NLI in competition? Have you seen this account of a Brendan Behan court case in 1959 on the Come Here to Me! blog?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] Excellent blog and great account of the Quare fellows encounter with the forces of law and disorder.  I knew one of the Guards, Garda McEntaggert, he would have been way too mild to be able to cope with Brendan in full flow!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] Loved "Which would be the greater insult - to apologise if I was not sincere or not to apologise?"

comment.author: 45282459@N02
comment._content: This is a very odd photo.  Things that should be clear are not... it's just strange.

comment.author: 88597506@N06
comment._content: Just to be a Lurganite pedant, this photograph appears to have been taken at the top of Castle Lane, whereas the companion photo (1990) is taken a good 200 yards further down High Street, at its intersection with Union Street

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/88597506@N06] You are right, rather than being pedantic, but as some comments above say, perhaps it was busy traffic, etc. that dictated the point from which the photo was taken?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons
